element_texts.text: Completed

Cher Ecrivain  -- 
V. Kay seems to have made a nice recovery after being repulsed. So has Maggy Daly. At least it seems so.
Put this in your Leninist computer and apply the output to the sad care of Mille de Beauvoir.
What a collection of shit-fumes. 
Banderia rassa trion fera*.   manny.
* red flag will triumph
Completed

Cher Ecrivain -

Here is the Bellows play preview announcement From the Village Voice

Remember when the good guy Dr. was in the santuan? santorium's of
B'way? With a good manager no tellin' where the Doc would be today.
But that's the other life. Some do, some don't.

The weather here has been magnificent. Cool nights & days and lots of

flowers & grasses. Can't remember when. Do this mean a hot summer?

 Alors, B.

on side; P.S. Gertrude Abercrombie my old pal, reminds me that 
James Blake will be in town this week. I believe I will take Dorothy F's {J.T. Frederick}
and tell him my time's engaged.
Completed

Mon

Dear Jim -
  Blue has gone on a fortnights cruise of uninhabited islands down thru the Keys. He scorned my advice to beware of

'canes and doesn't care for chichi costalano. His attitude toward Hemingway, he makes clear, has nothing to do with
ritin'. [sic] He out to prove that he is a more skilled man with rod & reel and creel. J.M. left burdened down with obscene
bait and expensive tackle, wearing a chartreuse boys cap.

 Do you have Zahera's address? I'd like to pen her a private note, a sub rosa billet deux,  unbeknownst to Ommie toy?  Get it?

My daily schedule is balled up since my directives were fut off. The other day I played 8 holes of golf before I found I was on
the wrong course.

 Is there a chance of your visiting the underline land of dreams /underline this winter. Just board that plane some midnight

and I pick up on you at the airport.

 I have a season ringside table reserved for visiting with us at Delicate Franks and the Jewel Box give me carte blanche.
   thine ?,  B.
Completed

Mon

 Your Reverence -
   On my way to see Zabasa and get my directives for this coming week. Somehow she missed me when

she passed out the onion skins on Sun and I'm at a complete loss.

  The Dr. is cooking for that French broad out in the dunes. She complained bitterly about the way he didn't

French-fry the potatoes.

 I'm still screwing around with the country club set and gettin' nowhere. More than likely I'll see you here

before I make what looks like my final trip South.

 My regards to those interested in them.       Yrs,   B.
Completed

Dear Jack -

Had a note from Nelson. He's building a bomb shelter on his estate. By selling space in advance he's made

more on the ca?e than on all his past writin?: That's progress and initiative and enterprise. His labor costs
are nix. Right next to his folly, there grows wild some of the best gange? in the midwest. He releases his help
for an hour each evening and they remain content and docile often wandering thru the patch.

Is Zahara working as a strip here in Miami? Thru an alcoholic haze I thought I saw her at the Jungle Culb [sic] the

other morning. This chick had the same demure expression and insisted on talking about Kierkegaard and Simone De.
George D.B. Huzza drove the cab that night. He's pimping on the Beach. Seems prosperous.

Cherry Blossoms Lane hasn't had a clear day all winter and the forecast is for more of the same.
How is it with you?     yrs.   B.
Completed

Thursday
Dear Jack -

Jean Abbott sends his love, wants you to hurry on down. Laid the arm on him with some Comments about the Dr.

He's mad to meet the N. now. Is going out of his way at the close of the season to visit Gary. He will bring his latest
gown? for a big drag - hope you are there.

I'll look around for that jumper. Will give you the ?ention? of the boys.   Heard from J.M.B. He's got bard-wire trouble.
 Best,   B.
Completed

Dear Jack -

Might be up for a gay ball. Things here are nowhere and there's been a hitch in the Fla proposition.
Haven't seen Whatson but I understand that all is love in his winter palace.
 Blake must be teamed up with the Lion or the Minotaur. he's been silent for a week or more.
The times are out of joint _______      yrs.  B.
Completed

June 25
Dear Jack -

I was distressed when I had your letter about the missing Anvil's and letters. If I had any

such in my possession you may be sure that I would turn them over to Wharton. I have
neither Anvil's or letters.

A couple of weeks ago I was at Finch's one Sunday of Yennon?. He was going thru some of

his papers and came on three copies of the Anvil. We decided to go to Wharton's and took the
Anvil's along for Wally. I  also gave Wally some letters from Blake and asked him to send them
to you.

At no time did I have the intention of embarrassing anyone. I can understand your concern in this

matter. Be assured that I did not have anything to do with the paper or magazines that are missing.
Completed

2  in pencil  [June 25]

 Since returning to E. St. Louis from Miami I've had nothing but bum kicks. First, I didn't get the job at the track

that I had been promised. Worse than that some politicians went out of their way to see that I wasn't employed.
Second: construction work has been miserably slow. I've been working about one day per week, just enough to
disqualify me from unemployment compensation.    I was very sensitive about owing money that I couldn't
repay so I delayed writing until I could do so. I had a feeling that things would get better but they seem to get worse.

I have nothing but feelings of gratitude and friendship for you and would never deliberately do anything to harm you

in any way.    If I can get in touch with Wally I'll have him confirm the Finch-Anvil thing.       yrs.  B.
Completed

P.S.

 Just talked to Finch and told him about the hassle. He said that the Anvil's came from a box he

had picked up at his mother's. One he hadn't seen since 1940. There are several more copies of the
Anvil which he says he will give to Wharton this Sunday.

 I hope when you have had time to look over your letter and Anvil files that the missing items will

turn up.
Completed

Sun.
Dear Jack -

 Miss Mason came thru here on her way to Cuba. She stopped for a day & got me hi. Said she had talked to you

and that Jack jr. was still out of service - that's great, hope he can hold out indefinitely.

Dr. Als, Golden Arm, is being pushed by all juice stands, travel agencies, gambling casinos etc. in a cheap edition.

He must be on his 2nd million.

J.M. Blue seems to have vanished. Lost in the mill dust of E. St. Louis. Last I heard he was trying to find his way to

Chicago. Hear anything?

 J. Blake is working for the State of Florida in a road camp near Jacksonville, has a two year contract.
Be seeing you about the time the first cuckoo makes it's appearance - got enough of this itshay.
 Miss Mason said you had a book due out soon. Is it a juve? Hope it makes a big noise. Let's hear from you sometime.
    yrs.   B.
Completed

Sat.

Dear Jack -
 Saw an old Buddy-Buddy of yours at the Ha Ha Club the other AM. Remember Jean Abbott? She's aged but not

as much as I have. I was a bit too bemused to get the complete story but I'm going back tonite and try again. I may
wind up in drag - seems to be the only thing left.

 J.M.B. is on the move again. He will probably call you as he moves North. Don't know his exact destination but I

do know that some people are giving him a bad time. Those Bob-wire Keysna? sure are busy.

 Hope you are O.K, and that things are going well with you. It may be necessary for me to come to Chicago before

spring. Seems that I've lost my touch. The old wrist has finally given out.     Yrs,  B.
Completed

Thurs

 Dear Jack -
   Finch said he saw you in Chicago last week-end. I'd like to get up but I must stay with 

my yokes now in order to survive this winter. I remember a nead? bus ride I took last
year and shudder at the prospect of a repetition.

 Miss Lovett, as you can see from the enclosed, has her underline eyes set /underline for a Dr. A. 

who could the mysterious friend be? Blake is having a ball in the Florida pen. although his lover was
paroled. Since then he has had a succession of friends who are no-where, he says.

 May the blessed saints preserve & keep you.      B.
Completed

Dear Daddy o -

 Saw A.S. McWhatron last week at his winter palace in University City. Never saw him so poised & composed

even during the IsKra? period.    He was elated about a letter from you concerning one of his reviews. Since the
purpose of my visit was to commend him for said review it was indeed a happy day.

 Looks like I'll have a job selling mutual tickets at Hialeah if I can get off my ass and get down there. Had to go all the way

to Ike via Sam Shantz to swing it. Tell Jimmy & M Jean I'll look for them at my window. Horse players never die, they go broke.

  Ever,   B.
Completed

Dear Pops -

 Let me here [sic] from you here at the Elms.
 Dr. A has gone into hiding in a sand dune. Refused to come out for even a minute.
 I may be around on your return. Hope we can have one last wild ball.
 Blue is probably going to go back to FlA with me.  Simone said I was guessing?. 

Should I be flattered or offended?   Best to all of those interested in them.

   yrs,  B.
Completed

Dear Vignette -

The Arthur news is from the New York Review of Books to which you should subscribe.

It is reminiscent of some of the John Reed type periodicals although more professionally done.
This is no reflection on Whatson or Balch.

I don't know what to make of Terkel. As a Thespian I would appreciate your comment. Has he

gone too far this time? They are gettin' Gold, man, very Gold.     yrs. Manny or Mcavery?
Completed

magazine page:  NEWS, FEBRUARY 17, 1968
File:Upper body of seated woman with hands folded    caption: Simone de Beauvoir
hand-written comment:  EARLIE FRANKIE GIGGI'S OLD LADY?
hand-written above article title  Some arthur!  SOME PROBLEMS!!
Problems of the affluent age:  A novel that offers no answers
LES BELLES IMAGES, by Simone de Beauvoir (Putnam, $4.95).
By Hayden Carruth
The problem of the female writer is not the simple, open-and-shut (shall we say?) struggle with males that it was once made out to be.  Why, for instance, at any literary cocktail party you attend, is it always the sweetly murderous voice of a female that rises to impugn the intelligence, motives, and ancestry of Simone de Beauvoir?  Or of Mary McCarthy, Denise Levertov, or any of half a dozen others?  Obviously, the pressures on them are multiplex.

   Nowadays our thoughts palpitate with problems of injustice.  Good enough; we can demand no less of ourselves.  Nor is the plight of intelligent women as acute as some others that occupy us.  But is it not more chronic?  It has been going on since the beginning of time.  It probably started in heaven.
   We don't even know what to call them.  "Female writer," "lady novelist," "[poetess" -- all stupid terms.
    SIMONE DE BEAUVOIR is as aware of this as anyone.  Indeed, she has discussed it at length in her famous book about women, "The Second Sex."  Yet she herself has failed to avoid the pitfalls, the pressures.  As a novelist she is certainly intelligent; she is skillful, sensitive, and more; and in the past she has produced big novels, like "The Mandarins," that have contained extremely fine writing.  But they  have been forced too awkwardly intense.  In them Mme. de Beauvoir has appeared to be trying too hard; a quite understandable response to the pressures exerted upon her.  
  Now she is 60 years old, though that is hard to believe, and in her new book she has taken the opposite tack:  she has produced a small, cool novel entitled, in both the English and French versions, "Les Belles Images."\   It is a story of the affluent society of the 1960s, the jet set.  It happens to concern the society of Paris, bu in our world today there isn't much difference, at this level anyway, between Paris and Rome and New York and Chicago--or any big  western city.  Strange though it may be, and significant as well, to see the French writing about themselves in terms we Americans use for our own society, this is exactly what we find in "Les Belles Images."  the heroine, named Laurence (and what might one say about that?), is a young woman who possesses a husband, two daughters, a lover, and a high-priced job in an advertising agency.  Her parents, representing the older, war-time generation, are divorced:  the mother living with italicized: her lover, the father in old-fashioned solitude.
   LAURENCE IS SURROUNDED, in short, by affluence:  beautiful modern dwellings, rich modern decor, expensive cars, expensive clothes, expensive parties; her life unfolds in an environment of glossy materialism, like the pictures  in fashionable magazines--italicized:  les belles images.
   Even so, here affairs go far from smoothly.  First, she is tired of her lover, though he is not at all tired of her, and she must find a convenient way to ditch him.  Second, her mother, undergoing the reverse crisis, has been jilted by her lover, and is threatening to break down.  Third, one of the children is heading toward the psychiatrist's office.  Fourth, Laurence and her husband are living on the unsatisfactory plane of successive mild quarrels and half-hearted reconciliation which characterizes stereotyped modernism; that is to say, Laurence is suffering from spiritual deracination, and she knows it.  Fifth, the one person with whom she would like to establish a genuine relationship, her father, the representative of old-fashioned humanism, remains insensitive to her predicament.  Sixth, Laurence is a woman; she is a successful professional woman, a victor in the sexual competition; but her triumph only makes her recognize that she has won it in a filthy business--advertising--and that it has robbed her of the one thing in life a woman ought to have, a close association with the children she has borne.
   In the end Laurence suffers a sort of a breakdown, during which she discovers a sort of an answer.  But we are unconvinced.
   MME. DE BEAUVOIR has set herself, in this novel, a conventionally difficult problem.  How do you write about uninteresting people, who nevertheless control society and hence are important in an interesting way?  The usual answer is that you write satirically, and in the past this is what Mme. de Beauvoir has done.  But now her caustic pen has been blunted by her fundamental sympathy for her dull people.  The dullness is not their fault, she says, and their predicament is a historical tragedy to which we have no ready solution.  Consequently, even though her book contains many shrewd insights ad some passages of dramatic interest, it is on the whole rather wooden.
    And, like most problem novels rather pat.  The millionaire manufacturer, the proletarian girl, the hedonist, the existentialist, the humanist, and then, sure enough, before the book is half-way through,  up turns the cabinet minister--like in all French novels.  Convention delegates, wearing the tags that tell who they are and what they stand for.  they come and go, and speak their set speeches, and all the narrative skill of Simone de Beauvoir, which is a good deal, cannot disguise their thematism.
   WELL, WOODEN AND PAT:  that's a Frenchman for you, and we can't blame it on Simone de Beauvoir.  Even in the novels of Genet and Celine, people talk like art critics.  Life in Paris is a continuous struggle for hauteur;  everyone knows that.  Yet if we can smile at this, and if we can accept the limits that are imposed on  the book by its essayistic function, "Les Belles Images" is well worth reading.  In its way, it is a frightening book.
    What can save Laurence?  Nothing.  she may come to understand the world of glittering surfaces that she has inherited;  indeed as an ad-writer she is better equipped than most of us to see through its flim-flam; but no amount of understanding will permit her to break out.  In order to re-establish contact with real human values she  would have to be born again, someone else altogether, living in a different place.  What lies unspoken at the center of this novel, unspoken but inescapable, is the suspicion that the future of Laurence and her fellow Parisians is being prepared, not in Paris, but in Phnom Penh, Khartoum, Kampala.  And what about Londoners?  New Yorkers?  Chicagoans?  The seed has ripened that was sown for so long.  A wild harvest is coming.

Italicized   Hayden Carruth is a widely known poet, novelist and literary critic.  A former Chicagoan, he lives with his wife and son on a Vermont farm.
line drawn to Hayden connecting to a hand-written comment Really J. S. Balch nee Travers
Completed

newspaper clipping
VALENTINE DAY HAS ADDED SIGNIFICANCE for Jack Benny, Hugh Downs and Art Hern.  They're Tuesday's birthday boys.  And a belated greeting on his 50th to Dan Herr of Chicago's lively publication, The Critic....Auto dealer Pete Eptseen, who experienced ecstasy and agony in 24 hours, raised a whopping $77,000 for charity at a closed-circuit telecast of the Frank Sinatra gala.   )The next day his auto showroom was bombed--but not like Dean Martin on the telecast.)

   THE WEEKEND  WAS SADDENED by the death of such long-time friends as A.J. Mustie, the pacifist;  Muggsy Spanier, the jazz great; Mrs. Chick Evans, wife of the golf champ, and Jack Sheridan, last of the Bughouse Square orators....Friends of Mr. Mustie will conduct a memorial service at Roosevelt U. on Feb.  21....Al Hamburg's description of Red China's Mao Tze-tung:  "Public Enigma No. 1."...And Ivan (Funny) Bunny) reports that Dr. Michael DeBakey, on Valentine Day,        

written after end of the second paragraph        Is he the last?  Brundige?
Completed

Dear Jack - Liberace has been running around Miami with a police escort, underlined: sirens and all.
Why don't he & Jack Eigen go back where they came from?

 Hialeoli? clases [sic] next Wednesday. Been looking for Jimmy & M. Jean, no see.

May drop in for a Bottle of nut brown ale in a week or two.   yrs.  B.
Completed

IMAGE;  photo of young girl in doorway holding framed picture of a serviceman
"What you're making may save my Daddy's - Da crossed out Buddy's life"
Dotty pointing at girl
Buddy Boy pointing to serviceman
Completed

Dear Mad-Dad -

 What's happening? Looks like Blue & I are forever barred from workin' at the Collin' due to that Homeric

ball we pitched with the Dr. I suppose the combination of Algren, whiskey and nigger women was just too much.
How did I know my boss was a square and related to the business agent?

Blake wants me to visit him at the Bayou Sou in St. Pete, Fla. I'm not sure what my role is to be, guest, inmate or lover?
 Whatson entertains nightly on a scale that would put the Butler's to shame. Stay cool.     B
Completed

Navy V-Mail
stamp PASSED BY NAVAL CENSOR  LGM  CENSOR'S STAMP
To  Miss JACKELINE  CONROY              From  [[STANLEY BAKER

CHICAGO ILL                                                 EANFRANC?
DEAR MiSS CONROY
ONLY A FEW LINE TO LET YOU HERE [SIC]
FROM ME AND THAT IM WELL AND DO HOPE YOU H..
THE En? MET A FRIEND OF YOU? BY THE 
NAME OF BUD FALLON AT THE HOLLYWOOD CATEEN?
AND HE GAVE ME  YOUR ADRESS [sic] SO I THOUGHT D? of

 STANLEY BAZLE [?]

Completed

Monday
Dear Jackie __

Life here is drab and bleak without the Gay ones. The Jewell Box has been closed

these past sad weeks and I and - crossed out am weary & sick.

Blue wrote from E. St. Louis that he had a campy time in Chicago.
 I received the shuffle news? - what is the Dr's address? I will hasten it off to him

air mail special.

 Let me hear from you in detail about the Dr's visit with  the Existentialists. Was Googy with

him? I wrote, what I thought, a whimsical note to one of  her [his?] friends. No response. what's the
matter with everybody? Is that the way to treat an ex-vet?
Completed

page extremely water damaged
Thursday
Dear Jack -

 I'm having that ..ation of Kathleen Windsor translated by the anliest? Ph & D in Miami.

He immediately noted that the Dr's name was inadvertently omitted and is writing to Studio..
to correct this monstrosity on the arts.

 What must I do to get into Yaddo? I'm an ex-veteran and a member of numerous fraternal, social,

political and labor organizations. I also know a guy named Riesto..? who works on a paper and I met
George B. DeHuzzar at a party one night several years ago. Are these qualifications sufficient? Maybe some
Strarety? could send a letter of recommendation! I've never been in  jail, etc. Nelson could, open the door
Richard, but he wouldn't. He has developed an amazing attitude that I'm insincere and flippant about such matters.

 With your help and a little from my precinct captain I feel almost certain that we'll be leaving for Saratoga together.
 I can't damaged.. all that canelat? ...mention this to J.W. Gunn, he might     do the damaged
  Yrs damaged, torn   Block     B.
Completed

time when I was in dire need of such friendship. My vanity was shattered, mental attitude negative
and I maintained a definite mood or rejection. You had much to alter this sorry combination of tendencies.
You built up the "Id". So I can't help it if I like you.

 I struck up an acquaintance with a couple of waitresses at Lost Lake, who go to Florida to "make shag?

while the sun shines." There is formation of an idea to this effect in my mind, but only in a nuclear state
as yet. Maybe it will materialize if the flesh be willing page torn

 Thir torn...hire. The job at....Everything is....close,,,a drum.
 Soon ....the side
 walk[?]....t. season
Completed

3

 opens next summer. There is no perspective to be gained in this dreary one horse town.
  Will in all probability go back to the "windy city" in a few weeks. I'm sending your book. It has

a rather used look after a years' time, but if you look real close you can still see the words. I enjoyed
reading it. I'll try to get Algren's new book. Remember the night we went to his house? Too bad those
slippers didn't fit you! Do you ever hear from the other author? the guy you went to St. Louis with.

  Love   page torn    ..ne
Completed

SAT
Dear Jackie -

 Comrade Vag called me the other day, rather he summoned me, to appear at a faction meeting.
  I was shocked, but delighted, when I found that it was an exclusive "boys" faction made up

of units from all over the country. I'll send you a copy of the agenda after I've passed it around here.

 Jack Stochel was there in drag as were the Hebe choral groups. Joseph Freeman did a mantch?

dance. I'm not sure but I think Hortense Barr was present. One particularly obnoxious & campy creature
came with a hideous golden costume. The arms were solid gold leaf. What do you make of all this?

Let me hear from you - soon.     Yrs.  B.
Completed

Sat
Dear Jacqueline -

Mr Brown will call you when he returns north in about a month. He will call in person to

prevent any possible mix-ups.

 Can you send me the name and address of the chick who was a friend of Guggenheimers?

I dis remember her name. I had her by your house one night. She lives with and works for
a head doctor.

 Blue is coming down in a week. He's going to apply for a DO's job here.
Completed

Is it OK if he uses Mother's name to collect money for the Urban League? He says

he'll cut Algren in.

 Send that name. The gal is older and interested in refinement & culture. She attended

some literary sessions.

 Best to all,    B.
Completed

Sat
Dear Jesse [? Jack?] -

 Sorry I missed your signal. I was half asleep - had just awaked from a nap after our

arduous day at Gulfstream Park. My luck has been no-where I'm in for a few C's. I'll
get it back tho ??

 Here's the situation with me here. Dorothy is leaving Monday the 7th of March. He-

mother will be down around the 1st of April. So if you can make it come down right away.
I know you don't relish living with Maggie.
Completed

2.

I'm sorry about Shots old Lady. There really isn't any thing to be done about it when it goes

that far at su?d oraye?.

 It's been frantic with Dot. V & Burden here. They tore hell out of everything. I'm looking forward to

a week of tranquil living.

 Better hurry on down, Jack If you could come by next week end maybe I could stall old lady

Butler for a couple of weeks.
Completed

3.

 I'll keep that signal in mind and I'll likewise use it when I have accosion [sic] to call you.
  If Orville can make it bring him along. There are plenty of beds and puss is available.
     Yrs,   B.   in pencil Some Puss  JB
Completed

Dear Nelsie -

 Balch has the fix here. Billie Dave the old r..s..ie fuer? is his pal and she is in. Can you send me a couple of chicks?

I can put them to work right away!!   Barbara is too old. Don't send her. Ma tha is out, too. she's a virgin, ain't she?

 James Light has been sending me some wires on the horses. I've made a big bundle. Balch and R. Rite & Motley are 

s?rmmming? to Israel this weekend to join Jarey Hoby?     Hi,  B.
Completed

Dear Nelsie -

 You got to be a spade to live in this torrid climate. F.M. Davis and Wogen Knecht have a cabana

for the season at the Roney Plaza. Will I be invited? Birdie Silverman & Hortense Barr spoke
briefly at the Legion convention. I couldn't make any sense out of what they said.

 Gil Rocke is organizing some kind of committee. Should I join? Balch, Teddy, underlined The

Tweed Suited Man /underline and Jerry Holey threatened to keep me out.

 Give my love to Richie, Opal, Rock, Willie, Lov.. d? and Betty.
 Conroy will be Librarian of Congress if Wallace is in.     Anxiously  B
Completed

Wed
Dear Jackeen -

 Couldn't resist sending you the enclosed. Could they be the "Hank" & "Bill" of Chicago?
 I may register for the fall semister [sic] at the U of Miami. The ex-veterans owe me some

schooling; about a year. Since you can't get to much learnian' [sic] I might as well chance it
Since I have a feeling I'll be called to the colors again very soon it seems futile to undertake
any serious project. Of course I have only one a hi?e to keep sh...in,  In your case it is some
what different.

 Do you have Miss Blankenship address at hand? I would like to send her a blast.
 Have a chick coming your way next week. Can have her call if you desire some mooky. Let

me know. Give my regards to unclear Peabody.    Yrs,  B.
Completed

Wed
Dearest Jackie -

 Thought you might find the enclosed interesting and that it might provide a nostalgic kick.
  Rushmore is now the chairman of the board and president emeritus of the Firebrick Co. Ever think

of the distance from Mexico, Mo to Long Island and a barbecue pit? And all because of a story in the Envil!! [sic - Anvil]

 How come the editor and circulation manager haven't received like recognition and acclaim?
  Balch isn't followin' writin' any more I heard. He's a comedian on the Borsht circuit, in a family act. Studs Terkel is his

body guard and manager. Goldie is writing the material. why don't you dig ?in?

  I've grown obese and gross this past year. Weigh almost 200 lbs. I'm up to a case of beer a day and I consume 8 benzedrine

sandwiches in the cool of the evening.

  If you look in the guest house you'll find God's Angry man? still writin' away.       Always,  B.
Completed

Dear Jackie -

 Having a mad ball with Birdie Silverman and Hortense Barr.  Barbara Lovett & Miss Blankenship are coming down

on a tour for the Dr's new book er oo. They are both going to be gold plated on the arms and do an intricate pitch.

 George B. De Huzzar and Harold Preece are scheduled to appear on a Seminar here next week. Huzzar is going to

be the Dr's advocate. Has the Dr been messin' with some of Preece's women?

 Is there any way that Wharton could be infloed? - influenced? to review underline The Arm /underline for the St Louis P.D.?
Completed

2

 I met an admirer of Harvey Webster's at Miami U the other day. He carries a copy of underline The ?ai? /underline

with him at all times. Keeps sayin' "I Know him personal, I shook his hand."

 My informants at Chicago U tell me that James Light has been signed by the Chicago Bears for the coming season. Is this so?
 Somebody also told me, erroneously I hope that ?am? Baxter had divorced his wife & married Jerry Haley.
 Blue reports that you are in fine shape and ready for that barbed wire enclosure
Completed

3.

  I've suddenly become interested in Party work. Think I'll take out a red card and see what happens.

I've tried everything else.

 I'd like to be assigned to the Pioneers or some ?ant movement. Good elements!
 Is it true that Joe Cullinane has taken Gil Green's job? I'd like to supplant Claude Lightfoot. Dig?
 See where your old pal M. Cowley came thru for Hisseroo.
 I'll never forgive you for not forcing me to marry Miss Raisers.
  My regards to all those interested in them and I do mean Thom Conroy.     Ever, B.
Completed

Tuesday
Dear Jack -

 Went over to Miami Beach last night. I can't understand the tolerant attitude adopted toward the boys.

It might be indifference on our Q? in squandons. Along Collins Ave in front of some of the fashionable hotels
I saw several big? broz faded in drag. I've seen other parts of town I faded several..... street.
faded text  ...prerequisite
Completed

Monday
Dear Jack -

 Enclosed needs no comment excusin that I'm living

only 6 blocks away.

 Some of the boys might be pursuaded [sic] to come over between shows for refreshments.

J.M. Blue says he might come down for the season to fish and swim.

 Saw the Dr. go by in a yacht yesterday accompanied by a gorgeous white haired woman.
Bird, in my faction see.  My love and felicitations to Doc, Tommy Wendell & Fif [torn]
      B
Completed

Dear Pops -

 Read your dispatch with great anxiety. I've wired Wharton imploring him to exercise extreme caution. I

suggested that F.M. Davis was envious and couldn't really stop a great artist. Would Davis understand if I
sent him a mild reproach and signed Wallie's name?

 How come the Dr. got second billing on that throw away? I'm filing a protest with H. Barr and the arrangements

committee.

 Will you accept and underline read /underline a wire concerning the above the night of Oct 27th? Naturally

it will be signed by Will Whatron.

 The boys at the Jewel Box delighted in your rebuke to the underline Squares /underline at the weather bureau.

I meet a Lion tamer there the other night. Half of the Legionnaires wanted to and some did get in drag. Better come on down.

 If I don't hear otherwise the wire will be sent to the underline Jack & Jill /end underline  
     Expectantly     B.
Completed

Wednesday

 Dear Jackeen -
  How about extending you vacation (cure?) for a week or two more and coming this way?
  H. Barr will prepare an agenda against your arrival and I will undertake your mundane needs,

puss, booze, gay one's, etc.

  Rockhouse Holt was the last author I saw, she came here to dig out some info on M. Bethune's

early sex life. She succeeded in adding to her libidinous experience but found little or nothing on the
behemoth. It has occured [sic] to me that you might continue her researches with some of the younger
splades. Having been a disciple of yours on several volley tours I have great confidence in your ability, as you must know.
Completed

2.

 What's the Dr. up to? Did he make the trip with De Huzzar? Please give me more exact information on his

arrival along with his Chicago phone and address. Danny Brown commutes between here and Chicago and has 
indicated that he would be enchanted to test the Dr. You and I of course, are already aware of the outcome, having
been made hip by Nina Mae.

 I am alarmed by J. Lights success. I've always said there's nothing like a college education and surely it's something

they can't take away from you.

 It is possible that I may enter the U of Miami in the fall to continue my work on history of J.S. Balch. It is going to

be a new type of biography. My reaction - my thesis is that Balch made his ? not the ? Balch. The school
authorities are overwhelmed and terrifically impressed.      Ever,  B.
Completed

UNIVERSITY OF MISSOURI-KANSAS CITY
College Of Arts And Sciences  Department of English
5315 Holmes
Kansas City, Missouri 64110
Telephone (816) 276-1305
March 6, 1972
Dear Jack,

 Thanks for the article on "The anvil" and "The New Anvil," and even more thanks for the Conroy

bibliography. I haven't thoroughly savored the tracts yet.   I trust Michel made it all right in and out
of Moberly. We enjoyed having both of you with us and we certainly want to have you back. One of
these days I am also going to pop in on you to go through your workroom for things to "borrow."

 David Ray is also much interested in your writing and in following up your contacts with other writers.
 Keep that autobiography coming along. I just finished a review for Sharpe on Himes' The Quality of

Hurt. I liked it much.               Hope to be seeing you soon,    Bob
Completed

in pencil  [1972]

College Of Arts And Sciences  Department of English
5315 Holmes
Kansas City, Missouri 64110
Telephone (816) 276-1305
Friday
Dear Jack,

I'm returning your letters by separate post, registered, insured, and well packed. We shall

need to keep the photographs a little longer. Please let me know if the letters do not arrive
in good condition.

 It was good to see you again and Katherine is enjoying your book very much. Thanks mucho.

David has asked me to write a brief review of Anyplace But Here for our fall issue, and I'm
looking forward to it.

 I'm also looking forward to reading the section of your autobiography when it comes. After this

fall Jack Conroy rides again.         Bob
Completed

in pencil [1973]
UNIVERSITY OF MISSOURI-KANSAS CITY
College Of Arts And Sciences  Department of English
5315 Holmes
Kansas City, Missouri 64110
Telephone (816) 276-1305
Tuesday
Dear Jack,

Thanks very much for sending me Tolson's last card to you. It arrived when I had all kinds of reports to make with end 

of the semester deadlines and many arrangements to make for our Institute. so, I haven't been as prompt as you requested
in returning it - sorry about that. But I hope I haven't worried you.

 Gareth & Sally had a great time visiting you, and I'm anxious to see the films they got. We had Sharpe over and looked

at the videotape of your Foolkiller performance. We are still keeping it under wraps so that NBC or CBS won't begin
competing for your services.

 Gareth & Sally got hitched last Saturday and I was "father" to the bride. Michel wrote briefly about hearing of all your

activities lately. We're looking forward to seeing him soon.

 Thanks also for the clipping from Moberly about the Tolson review. It's curious how Tolson news does and does not get around.
    Regards,    Bob
Completed

May 2, 1975
Dear Jack,

 Since it will be quite late by the time I am able to drive you back to Moberly Saturday night, and since I will

have driven quite a distance that day coming and going, I wonder if you could put me up for the rest of that night
so I could return to K.C. fresh Sunday morning.

 In any case I plan to be there about 2:30 p.m. to bring you and Gladys to K.C. for dinner and the graduation

ceremony. Looking forward to seeing you then.        Regards,   Bob

UNIVERSITY OF MISSOURI-KANSAS CITY
College Of Arts And Sciences  Department of English
5315 Holmes
Kansas City, Missouri 64110
Telephone (816) 276-1305
May 16, 1975
Dear Jack, Doctor of Humane letters,

 Here are a couple of copies of the Star article. You may have some mixed feelings about it. An interview never comes out exactly the way

you hope it will but I like it very much. It is a much more solid and yet responsive piece than I would have expected in the Star.

 Thanks also for your Anvil anthology. I was particularly caught by a poem from an old friend, Alvin Foote. Your bio-note didn't say much

about him. But I knew him in the early '50's where he very reluctantly enrolled in a Ph.D. program for a couple of years. He had been doing
PR work for a couple of colleges and consistently had women and alcohol problems. He never got over his divorce from his first wife, the
suicide death crossed out of his father-in-law and the Catholic priest's refusal to bury him, the end of the Spanish Civil War when he
was about to sail from New York, and his love for the mountains. Last I heard from him he was teaching in a California State College and
apparently willingly submissive to a woman who was keeping alcoholic needs in check. Both Sylvia and I liked him immensely.

 I hope you got back to Moberly without being seriously damaged by the ordeal we put you through. It was good seeing you again, and I

hope we have another less strenuous chance soon.      Regards,  Bob*

*  He is Robert H. Farnsworth
Completed

 Good luck and fraternal wishes     Jim Fanell

May 22/67  NY
Dear Jack:

 Mike Gold passed on. His Jews Without Money - I insist is a good book.
  In your autobiography you will be fully justified if you think you should state that the

major reason Mike Gold attacked me was my review of The Disinherited. in The Notion.

 This is true, and I shall take no offense at
Completed

in pencil [May 22, 1967]
2
your writing what is true. This letter confirms what I say. We must keep the record clear and truthful,
and you are fully justified if you deem it proper or necessary to make the statement of truth I give
you here.

 There are not many of us to keep the record clear, Jack.    If you write of? Mike, you are justified

in saying that Mencken
Completed

in pencil [May 22, 1967]
3
admired some of Mike's writing, as he did of yours.

 I am working hard, and in pretty good health. I am working out Actimes?

to be free of publishers.   I was not precisely unfriendly to you, but I could
have been more friendly in 1935, and I recognize that, and also, that when you
came to my Sherwood Anderson lecture in Chicago in 1949, I should have gone to you,
Completed

4
shaken hands, and spoken.  I should add that many times, I did inquire after you, of Dorothy and
others, and was glad for good news.

 and you can say, that after the years, we have a better feeling toward one another than most of our

contemporaries.  I hope that your autobiography goes well. And that you are happily at work and
in good health.

 Fraternally
  Jim Farrell
Completed

in pencil [May 22, 1967]

wrote that if Western civilization develops a new type, it will be in the American Mid-West. You
You might have to cite this.   My 41st book comes out this year - New Years Eve: 1929.
I keep lots going.

 Young writers - I find few. One not so young now, Kay Cecillis. Greek writing in English,

wrote a good book, No Name on the Streets. I republished a comment

of prose? on Jack London's underlined: The Iron Heel.    It, and underlined: Martin Eden, remain to me very good books.

 If you touch on painters - Raphail [sic: Raphael] Sayer - he is good.  And dont forget Art Young.
 There's a sociological book with some value, underlined: Main Street and the Middle Border  Auslenn? - Atherton, U of Indiana Press.

Do you like George Ade? We all owe him something, I believe. And Finley Peter Dunne?. I think he was a great writer.

 On names and desbucir?.

IOWA STATE COLLEGE
Of Agriculture And Mechanic Arts
AMES, IOWA
Department of English and Speech
Jan. 20, 1950
Dear Jack -

 Gert Soltner tells me that you have been good enough to read my manuscript.

Thanks very much. I am enclosing a dollar's worth of stamps, so that you can
send the novel on to someone who might publish it, or return it to me.

 I remember gratefully that you published my first short story - it has been a long drought.
   Leonard Feinberg
Completed

June-11-60
Dear Jack & All,

A Hasty note to say we will be out of town from 12-16-. Mother does not live with me but next door.

She is recouperating from a serious operation done on June 13- She is doing fine but at 83 it takes a
while to get one's strength back. However Dr. says she is doing fine. - Had a piece of the large vein
in abdomen removed & replaced by a plastic tube. On the table 4 hrs. -

Please plan to come & have dinner with us if you can on the 23 or 24.  Those are my days off.
  (over)

Note: date may be off; operation on June 13, letter dated June 11
Completed

I hope you can so we can see each other. Am still working.

Drop a line if you can & let me know what day.

So glad you came back.

  Love   Orienne
Completed

address label
Orienne Fennelly
Route 2, Box 291
Troutdale, Ore. 97060
12-27-64
Dear Gladys & Jack.

 Was so happy to have your note and learn of your future visit to Portland. Please, will you stay

with me while here? - Would love to have you & I have plenty of room - tho my Apt. is small.
I had an apt. built in the basement of the house Mother lived in. It is ample, with full bath & all
facilities.   When I got the upstairs
Completed

cleaned up & arranged - will rent it. Have my house next door (where P. & I lived) rented to a nice young
couple with a 6 mo old baby. They both work so are not at home much - however they do take good care
of the place.

 I am working - "on call" - now. I specialed? a terminal cancer case from Feb- to August - 1964 & when she passed

on I needed extra time to move into my new apt. & also to care for Mom as I didn't have anyone here then. I get
from 10-15 days per month & that pays my bills & leaves me time for extra curricular activities.  I had a lovely &
competent lady with Mother  the last 2 Months (mom was in bed most of the time - just nrak? -  She suffered much
& I wouldn't wish her back under those conditions.

 I was back to see Dad & Caroline in October & saw Many mar [sic] of my friends & Relatives than in 63. Was so glad

to  visit with Margaret.

 Am going to work 11PM-7Am shift tonight - Yesterday I worked 3pm-11pm - I work any shift (there is one from 6:30AM-3Pm)

and know all the pts & routines ^ so that I can work on any ward so I get all the work I want. I have been there 8
Completed

years. Still love the work & hope my health continues so I can work many more. Mother was 87 dad is 89
& still drives his own car - I am 66 & no ill health so - maby [sic] I'll live to be 100 - Who knows. I feel
one is only as old as his mind & I try to keep mine working.

 Be sure & stay with me when here - will look forward to it
   Love    Orienne

I'd like to hear about that trip!
Completed

in pencil  Fennelly, Orienne [no date]
Otp Fenelly
Wednesday - July 25 - At Home
Dear Folks:

 At last we have some prints to send you. We shot they turned out pretty good. The ones we took at

Mt Hood are still in the camera & will send as soon as we have them.  We certainly enjoyed your visit &
hope you will do it again. We have finished the house & completed the paint job, too. It looks real good.

 Last nite we had our joint Birthday party out here. Mother was 79 July 13 - Mary (the girl Mom & I raised)

July 24 - Mine July 26 - Kenny July 30. We first have one dinner for
Completed

all of us. Had fun. Hope you had a nice trip home.

 We have been having som [sic] really hot weather 85 [degrees] today. Our basement

is very cool so we stay down there.

 Hope you like the pictures.  Drop us a line when you can.
   Love    Orienne & philip
Completed

letterhead
LAZY ACRES MOTEL  image of fisherman
E.R. Drake Proprietor
Phone 5-9081
Rest Awhile on the Rogue River at
Gold Hill, Oregon
March 2
Dear Jack & Family -

 Thank you so much for your book. I find it most interesting.Yours & those of your chosen Authors,

descriptions are so graphic - I see pictures so redily [sic] in all description, so you know what I am looking
at when reading some of your passages - My husband is very appreciative of humor & I feel you two would
have much in common. It has been his ambition to write, but so far hasn't. Who can tell why -

 I hope you will visit us here
Completed

2
letterhead
LAZY ACRES MOTEL  image of fisherman
E.R. Drake Proprietor
Phone 5-9081
Rest Awhile on the Rogue River at
Gold Hill, Oregon
in the West this summer.

 Haven't met Jack Jr. yet but hope to soon.. We are on the road now - Looks interesting doesn't it? - 

I fished on the North Umpqua  river Saturday & caught a 23 1/2 steelhead. arrow pointing to image of fisherman on letterhead
We have some wonderful country here do come out & investigate.

 Philip is N.W. Representative for Pioneer Rubber Mills of Calif. We travel thru Oregon - S. Wash & N. Cal. - A very interesting

life. We have a small house - Glorified Motel - on a Lake - in fact between 2 lakes - You see I am still a Country Jake at heart &
am showing P. the joys of the   (over)
Completed

simple life.

He is the brain of the family & is rather nervous & high strung.  We do enjoy our life together & our

travels & the people we meet.   Thanks again for remembering me & if possible come & see us

 The Best,      Cousin Orienne

The box numbers in our locality have recently been changed Ours is now  Rt 2  Box 291
Troutdale, Or.    Would enjoy hearing from you and about your family.
Completed

in pencil Ferguson, Irene (1986?)
image of house, tree, snow & Santa's reindeer
Dear Jack,

Hope you are doing well now & that you licked the OA bug for a time. You are rembered [sic]

well at the company. The advisory board was reactivated at a meeting in October John Goodlad
sung your praises while briefing the new board. The old man was there - he's blind, confined to a
wheel chair, but has a sharp mind - along with his grandson Peter Ewing, who now runs the company.
It's hard to believe I've
Completed

been in "Downey's Inferno" for 30 years.

 Hope you can read my writing. Mark is here typing a paper for an MBA class. You

never get rid of children and I'm glad for that.

 Happy holidays to you,    Irene
Completed

postcard
image of building, river, boat
Completed

postcard
in pencil Irene & Dick

Escaped again! Amsterdam is swinging - especially the Rembrandtsplein. Never fear -

just 1/2 day was spent in the bldg. on the picture. The Dutch gin - geneva - you drink
straight out of a shot glass - need about five to start feeling it. The beer is mellow - I'm
going to try to get old man Ward to reimburse me for some of this research for New Standard.

  Irene & Dick

Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave.
Moberley, [sic] Mo. 65270   U.S.A.
